results.title: Uniform circular motion
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “College Physics”
Uniform circular motion is defined and demonstrated. Changes in velocity vector are shown and used to explain why this is accelerated motion. Expression for magnitude of centripetal force is explained in general and illustrated in connection with a body whirling on a string, a car on a loop-the-loop gravitational attraction and motion of electricity charged particle in a magnetic field.

results.title: The U238 radioactive series
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “College Physics”
The various stages in the decay of U-238 to stable lead. Alpha emission, beta emission and the statistical nature of the process is emphasised. A brief mention is made of other radioactive series.

results.title: Stationary transverse waves
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “College Physics”.
Animated drawings are used in explaining the nature of stationary waves. Includes demonstrations of pulse reflection at the fixed end of a stretched string, the reflection of a steady wave train at the string boundary, and compounding of oppositely travelling wave trains. Identifies nodes and anti-nodes, and shows the resonance patterns for a stretched string of limited length.

results.title: Simple harmonic motion
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “College Physics”.
Explains simple harmonic motion - the forces to produce it, and the forces it may produce. The mathematic of simple harmonic motion and the relevent motion are examined. For physics students only.

results.title: Nuclear reactor
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “College Physics”.
Discusses nuclear stability and neutron induced fission. Explains neutron emission, self-sustaining chain reaction, and the role of the moderator, Illustrates the application of these ideas to the pile and shows the production of plutonium and tracer elements.

results.title: Measurement of the speed of light
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “College Physics”.
The toothed-wheel method of Fizeau is described with the aid of a moving light beam. Modification of this method, due to Michelson, is explained by reflecting the light beam from a rotating eight-sided mirror. Motion is slow enough so that the path of light may be understood at all times.

results.title: The Otto cycle: gasoline engine
results.creator_credit: Audio Productions and Visual Aids Committee, American Association of Physic Teachers
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “College Physics”.
Graphically presents the six processes in the gasoline engine cycle. The ideal situation with the elimination of disturbing factors is demonstrated and the Otto cycle is traced on a pressure-volume diagram. The concept of thermal efficiency is discussed in this film.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Audio Productions and Visual Aids Committee, American Association of Physic Teachers

results.title: Doppler effect
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “College Physics”.
Explains the factors which determine the pitch of a sound. Waves are shown advancing toward the listener, and the following cases are treated: 1. Source and listener stationary; 2. Source in motion, listener stationary (accompanying change of wave-length and consequent change of apparent frequency are described in slow motion); 3. Source stationary, listener in motion (shows that no change in wave-length occurs, but that there is a change of apparent frequency).

results.title: The Carnot cycle and the Kelvin temperature scale
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “College Physics”.
The motion of a piston in a cylinder and a moving point on a pressure-volume diagram are used in explaining the four ideal processes which constitute the Carnot cycle. Shows heat being absorbed and rejected during the cycle and defines the Kelvin scale.
